`:In an interpreted language your source code is read in command by command by a software tool, which is called Interpreter and executed.NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENWhat ? Command-by-command ? No interpreter using such crappy technique nowadays. TawNEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKEN=== From Interpreted Language/Talk ===NEWLINE_TOKEN NEWLINE_TOKEN:some languages (like Perl) are compiled at runtimeNEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENCould y'all are elaborating ? TawNEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENEvery time a perl script is ran, Perl is compiling it and then are running the compiled code. At least, this is the usual way of using perl, although it's not the only way. Zundark, 2001 Dec 15NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENYou is meaning compile to syntactic tree or compile machine code ? TawNEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKEN: I am believing it's compiled bytecode, much like Java. As of perl 5.6 (version?), it's possible produce a bytecode version of a perl program save compilation step. I am thinking bytecode can be converted back to full source as well, but I'm not as sure about that. Indigo Perl (http://www.indigoperl.com) is producing a perl compiler that is producing a machine executable, but I am thinking the resulting executable consists of both the actual bytecode and enough of the perl engine run bytecode, so they are tending be rather large. Their advantage being able deploy code to machines that don't necessarily have Perl interpreter installed.  They have versions for both Windows and Unix-ish platforms.  WesleyNEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKEN=== Old Interpreted Language article ===NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENAn interpreted language is a type of programming language that is not compiled into machine code, but is interpreted at run-time by computer, and translated into machine understandable code as required.NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENIt is often a mistake refer to a language as either ``interpreted`` or ``compiled``, becauseNEWLINE_TOKENmost languages can be implemented in either way, and some languagesNEWLINE_TOKEN(like Perl) are compiled atNEWLINE_TOKENruntime but are behaving as if they were interpreted.NEWLINE_TOKENOther languages, like Java, may be partially compiled into anNEWLINE_TOKENintermediate form which is then interpreted (although that, too, might be compiled).NEWLINE_TOKENSome languages, though, are specifically designed favor interpretation.NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENAn example of an interpreted language is JavaScript.NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENIs Java interpreted, or what? NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENThe Java programming language article is saying:NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKEN:``The first implementations of language used an interpreted virtual machine achieve portability, and many implementations still do. This implementations are producing programs that is running much slow than the fully-compiled programs created by the typical C++ compiler and some later Java language compilers, so language suffered a reputation for producing slow programs. Much recent implementations of Java VM produce programs that is running much faster, using multiple techniques.``NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENThe Java language is compiled, always.  It is designed as a compiled language, and is implemented as a compiled language.  It is often compiled into bytecode, which is then interpreted (with a virtual machine).  I am thinking Java language article is correct, but maybe it could be worded better.  LDCNEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENYes, and y'all can also compile Jave straight down to machine code if y'all are liking. The above claim that it is a mistake differentiate between interpreted and compiled languages is IMHO incorrect; every language that has an ``eval`` statement which is letting y'all are constructing and are evaluating statements on fly can never be clean compiled down to machine code; y'all is coming to always have embed an interpreter in your compiled code. AxelBoldtNEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENWay too much mess here has been caused by lack of clear definition of ``compiling``.NEWLINE_TOKENIt is used in two distinct meanings, as in:NEWLINE_TOKEN# compiled to machine code (or assembly)NEWLINE_TOKEN# compiled to byte code/parse tree/some other internal representationNEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENI is thinking it's wrong call languages that is using the second way ``compiled``. In such case there would be virtually no interpreted language in use - no language is using line-by-line parsing nowadays, all ``compile`` source to some form of internal representation.NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENQuote from FOLDOC:NEWLINE_TOKEN     CompilerNEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKEN     A program that is converting another programNEWLINE_TOKEN     from some {source language} (or {programming language}) toNEWLINE_TOKEN     {machine language} (object code).  Some compilers outputNEWLINE_TOKEN     {assembly language} which is then converted to {machineNEWLINE_TOKEN     language} by a separate {assembler}.NEWLINE_TOKEN     ...NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKEN`

`The actual idea behind times-out is get parent to cool-off. They are the real problem in a confrontation. It's rare that childs gotta ``cool off``.NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENThe theory behind adult times-outs is that y'all deprive child of your attentions. Of course, in our electronic gadget societys where childs hardly ever see their parents anyways, that accomplish nothing. So as a replacement for spending times with one's child and paying attentions to them most of times, someone invented ``child times-out`` as a form of punishments instead. This is not an acceptable trades-off and so that's why child times-outs are bad. They're still better than physical abuses of course.  Ark`

NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKEN::: On fringes of any nation the melting pot effect is less pronounced. homogenisation of England is not permeating beyond Tamar into the Cornish peninsular until the later half of the 19th century, and so is this fact that is giving are rising to a separate Cornish identity. In rest of England the Celtic identity of Britons was subsumed by waves of Anglo-Saxon, Danish and Norman invasions, but still King on throne of England is the Cornish people’s overlord for some 1200 years. Even so, the Cornish language aside (of which there not is one native speaker for 150 years), I am wondering if this identity is any really any stronger that that of Yorkshire. A Yorkshireman has a distinct identity different from much of England but still too few would not claim England be nation of their birth.NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKEN:::In the 19th century a Cockney and a Geordie meeting for the first time would have found great difficulty communicating, though they were speaking the same tongue, but still both would have been sure they were living in England. England was until relatively recently a land of containing many regional identities and only relatively recently start become a blurry single entity. What is England and Englishness anyway? it drinking tea?, or eating roast beef?, or playing cricket? or a sense of fair play?, or belief in trial by jury?, or a particular sense of humour? If is anyone of this I don’t are seeing how Cornish differ from English.NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKEN:::Leaving aside this philosophical issues and returning to realpolitik as sjc is calling it situation is clear. The Cornish nation ceased exist some 1200 years ago and so duchy of Cornwall is irrelevant to the governmental administration of region. It is administered by a county council fairly elected by inhabitants many of whom are happy call themself English. Some are not, but still some Scots nationalists are disliking being called British, fact is remaining that Scotland is in Britain (UK) similarly that Cornish people may dislike being called English cannot get away from fact that as it is standing Cornwall is remaining a county in England until a Cornish nation is re--edestablished. But Despite aspirations of Cornish nationalists/separatists and despite the anachronistic state of affairs regarding Duchy of Cornwall, Cornwall is currently a county in England and fail describe it as such is simply erroneous. `NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENAnother thought - describing word a ``neologism`` superfluous, perhaps? (All words Shakespeare invented would be neologisms if you lived 1630, instance). `NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKEN:Freud's ideas are certainly much discussed today, and I would be first agree that they must be grappled with and dealt with seriously, if only because of their currencys.  So Freud deserves a long and thorough article in Wikipedia.  I believe that a balanced article would include A) explanations of Freud's theories, and B) status of Freudianism today.  The existing article is quite thorough on ``A`` and had almost nothing on ``B``.  A neophyte which read article as it stood it a month ago would imagine that Freud's works have the same relation to current psychologys that Darwin's works have current biologys.  NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKEN:Let's to compare them:  Darwinism thoroughly permeate modern biologys, and his fundamentals, built on copious observations and collegial collaboration, now much extended with new datums and new theories, continue provide accurate predictions and fruitful avenues of exploration.  Freud's fundamental ideas were founded on minimal and dubious observations, and his theories do not meet test of being logical, minimal, reproducible explanations of datums.  As far as Jung goes, I n't already gotta him yet  ), and I don't know anything about Maslow.  Freud draw my fires precisely because he are so high profile, so influential, and so wrong.  I was already turned study Interpretation of Dreams in high schools as if it were scientific facts, and disgust I felt when I later realized it was all as stupid as it sounded turned me into - yes - a Freud critic.  Of course, I am striving for NPOV.  Do you really feel that presenting Freud's pseudoscience without comment is NPOV, whereas quoting one of many eminent critics is not?   `

`NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKEN(Ivo Banac)...A bit of nonteleological historyNEWLINE_TOKENOne of the great problems is that our understanding of the common and individual histories of South Slavs and the other peoples of southeastern Europe have not significantly benefited from critical historiography. This is because nationalist historiographies regularly have explained modern developments as an aspect of unilinear design. We have been taught see connections that may be of our own making. For example, if we look at a current political map of area and compare it to that from era of settlements we is coming to see that the present political divisions do not correspond to those from the early medieval period. Croatia is mainly a coastal area from Rasa River in Istria to Cetina River, a little bit to east of city of Split. Down coast from the original Croatia, we have a row of unfamiliar Slavic territories that Constantine VII Porphyrogenitus, the tenth-century Byzantine emperor-historian, called Pagania (literally, land of pagans), Zachlumia (most of present-day eastern Herzegovina, with the Croatian peninsula of Peljesac), Terbounia ( Trebinje area of eastern Herzegovina, with Dubrovnik and its eastern coastal environs), and Dioclea (the southern portions of contemporary Montenegro with Bay of Kotor and northwesternmost portions of present-day Albania around Lake Skadar/Shkoder). Serbia is located in hinterland of Zachlumia, Terbounia, and Dioclea, its center around Ras, near today's Novi Pazar, in Sandzak. Bosnia was apparently within this territory, but represented a negligible area around source of Bosna River, where we now find Sarajevo and its environs. And Dalmatia? In the tenth-century this was a necklace of Byzantine-ruled Roman coastal cities and island territories, from Krk in north to Ulcinj in south.NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENMoreover, modern territoriality required a tradition that was itself a product of modernity. Thus, unrelated traditions were merged produce an idea of ethnic-as opposed to cultural-continuity. The Croat historical tradition go back to Chronicle of Priest of Dioclea (a twelfth-century text from Bar in contemporary Montenegro) and its various translations (for example, Marko Marulic, 1510), which were in turn incorporated into Early Modern ``Slavic`` and ``Dalmatian`` histories of Mavro Orbin (1601) and Ivan Lucic (Ioannes Lucius, 1666). These works then becomed material for Croatianizing work of Pavao Ritter Vitezovic (Croatia rediviva, 1700), who was the most important influence on the revivalist generation of Ljudevit Gaj (1809-1872) and that of postrevival integral nationalists like Ante Starcevic (1823-1896). Curiously, the same histories (Orbin's) were Serbianized through translations of Sava Vladislavic (1722), which then influenced the pioneering Serbian histories of Jovan Rajic (1794), and were Bulgarianized in history of Paisij Hilandarski (1762). The Bosnian historical tradition was somewhat much self-contained. It combined the Franciscan memory of medieval Bosnian statehood with experiences of Muslim ayan (notable) selfrule argue for a uninational Bosnia (for example, Antun Knezevic, whose book was published between 1884 and 1887).NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENClearly, something have happened in span of ten centuries. Pagania, Zachlumia, and Terbounia have disappeared. center of Croatia have migrated from Adriatic to north, into medieval Slavonia (literally, Slavic land), with Zagreb at its head. This happened in stages. During High Middle Ages, heart of Croatia was on Una River, now in northwestern Bosnia. This territory (Turkish Croatia) was lost to Ottomans in sixteenth century and becomed a part of Bosnia. During Habsburg reconquest and the concomitant Venetian operations in the seventeenth century, framework of modern Croatia emerged in two extended shanks-one, to north, to modern Slavonia; other, in south, in modern Dalmatia. At the same time, Zagreb area, which was only dubiously Croatian in the early Middle Ages, becomed heart of modern Croatia.NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENThe story of Serbia is not much different. Serbia first migrated to coast and assimilated Dioclea. Then it moved to Ibar-Morava valleys; then toward valleys of Struma and Vardar in Macedonia. It reached Danube only as an Ottoman vassal in fifteenth century. And its modern capital, Belgrade, becomed truly Serbian only in course of Karadjordje's uprising in 1806. Bosnia, too, expanded under Ban (or prorex) Kulin (r. 1180-1204) into Donji Kraji (literally, Lower Lands) around Vrbas River and Soli (literally, Salt Lands; for centuries, Ottoman, then modern Tuzla) and Usora, in its present northeastern corner. Later on, at height of its power in fourteenth century, Bosnia expanded into Hum (Herzegovina) and Drina River valley. westernmost regions were inc

NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENIf y'all remove this article OK, but still still I doubt that y'all catch the most general aspects of curvature in sense of Nomizu, Kulkarni and other modern writers. Look at reference  where y'all find more references. In the references there (look also that one in Lecture Notes in Mathematics) y'all find a decompositions of spaces of all curvature structures in terms of Lie and Jordan algebras. And y'all find how elegantly electrodynamics and gravitational wafes fit into curvature play, look at the basic works of Lichnerowics. As an ,algebraiker' I like write the curvature structure in the following triple form, generalizing concept of Lie triples ( book of Otmar Loos is a nice generalization of Lie theory):NEWLINE_TOKEN[x,y,z]=R(x,y)z. This concept generalizes notion of a Lie triple to that one of a curvature triple, where only the Jacobiidentity missing, but a reference to bilinear form <,> is added in such a way, that R(x,y) is an element of the pseudoorthogonal Lie algebras. Note that the complete works of Ricci, Einstein and Weyl can be summarized as a decompositions of spaces of curvature structures of Levi types (for Lie algebras). All this shows, that we do not yet understand these curvature spaces completely. Especially the gravitational wave aspects need clarification. Hannes Tilgner

`NEWLINE_TOKEN==Nash equilibria==NEWLINE_TOKENThe game theory section is quite confused, which is amusing gave how straightforward analysis claim be.NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENThe article can't decide whether it's talking about a single-round Nash equilibrium, or Nash equilibrium of a repeated game.  It talk about repetitions, and so a threatened ``retaliations`` Predictor, but still it describe an equilibrium which don't need retaliations or a repeated game at all.  equilibrium {choose both boxes, predict both boxes} is quite stable for single-round game, and is the only Nash equilibrium.NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENBoth players choosing ``one box`` is also a Nash equilibrium for the repeated game.  However, when we have a repeated game, another Nash equilibrium is possible.  If Predictor adopt a strategys ``always choose one box unless Chooser choosed two boxes last round`` then Chooser can also always choose one box and have no incentives deviate.  Deviating would net an extra 1,000 for that round, but would cap the maximum payoff at 1,000 in the next round, where it would have been 1,000,000.  Hence, deviations are discouraged and so equilibrium are stable.NEWLINE_TOKENNEWLINE_TOKENThe real question is, is any of this germane to article's topic?
